articles.title: Accelerometry
articles.contents:
Preprocess
The original accelerometry data shows the cumulative probabilities for acceleration of 1, 2, 3 milligravities, etc.
This preprocess transformed them into probability mass on each acceleration value.









Probability Mass Table (for the first 500 participants)




Accelerometry visualization (for the first 200 participants)




Interpretation
In the visualization, the probability mass functions follow a “3-peak” pattern.
It has been validated for all users with compliance.
3 peaks appear at 1, 20 and 200 milligravities.
Activity amount
Based on the acceleration cutoffs, the total probability within each range can measure the amount of different activities.
1 - 19 milligravities: LOW intensity activity
20 - 95 milligravities: MIDDLE intensity activity
100 - 1900 milligravities: HIGH intensity activity
Activity Amount Table




Bivariate
Accelerometry ~ Activity
Categorical activity variables

 [1] "number_of_daysweek_walked_10_minutes_f864_0_0"                       
 [2] "number_of_daysweek_of_moderate_physical_activity_10_minutes_f884_0_0"

[14] "ipaq_activity_group_f22032_0_0"                                      
[15] "above_moderatevigorous_recommendation_f22035_0_0"                    
[16] "above_moderatevigorouswalking_recommendation_f22036_0_0"

Activity amount vs. activity’s categories







Accelerometry ~ Sleep
Variables related to sleep conditions

 [1] "sleep_duration_f1160_0_0"                                           
 [2] "getting_up_in_morning_f1170_0_0"                                    
 [3] "morningevening_person_chronotype_f1180_0_0"                         
 [4] "nap_during_day_f1190_0_0"                                           
 [5] "sleeplessness_insomnia_f1200_0_0"                                   
 [6] "snoring_f1210_0_0"                                                  
 [7] "daytime_dozing_sleeping_narcolepsy_f1220_0_0"                       
 [8] "trouble_falling_or_staying_asleep_or_sleeping_too_much_f20517_0_0"  
 [9] "did_your_sleep_change_f20532_0_0"                                   
[10] "trouble_falling_asleep_f20533_0_0"                                  
[11] "sleeping_too_much_f20534_0_0"                                       
[12] "waking_too_early_f20535_0_0"                                        
[13] "degree_bothered_by_trouble_sleeping_in_the_last_3_months_f21061_0_0"
[14] "overall_health_rating_f2178_0_0"                                    
[15] "neuroticism_score_f20127_0_0"                                       

Activity amount vs. sleep conditions




Statistical Analysis



According to Central Limit Theorem, mean of users’ activity amount with medical condition (‘best’ or ‘worst’) approximates a normal distribution.
Thus the mean of activity amount difference between ‘best’ and ‘worst’ should also has a normal distribution.
p-value = minimal { p-value(mean difference > 0), p-value(mean difference < 0) }
If p-value << 0.5, the activity amount difference between ‘best’ and ‘worst’ is significant.

articles.title: Clustering
articles.description: Apply clustering to transform multiple sleep variables into a single outcome variable.
articles.contents:
Baseline sleep variables

 [1] "sleep_duration_f1160_0_0"                                           
 [2] "getting_up_in_morning_f1170_0_0"                                    
 [3] "morningevening_person_chronotype_f1180_0_0"                         
 [4] "nap_during_day_f1190_0_0"                                           
 [5] "sleeplessness_insomnia_f1200_0_0"                                   
 [6] "snoring_f1210_0_0"                                                  
 [7] "daytime_dozing_sleeping_narcolepsy_f1220_0_0"                       
 [8] "trouble_falling_or_staying_asleep_or_sleeping_too_much_f20517_0_0"  
 [9] "did_your_sleep_change_f20532_0_0"                                   
[10] "trouble_falling_asleep_f20533_0_0"                                  
[11] "sleeping_too_much_f20534_0_0"                                       
[12] "waking_too_early_f20535_0_0"                                        
[13] "degree_bothered_by_trouble_sleeping_in_the_last_3_months_f21061_0_0"

Louvain Clustering
The Louvain method is an unsupervised algorithm to detect communities in large networks. It does not require the input of the number of communities nor their sizes before execution. It maximizes a modularity score for each community, where the modularity quantifies the quality of an assignment of nodes to communities. This means evaluating how much more densely connected the nodes within a community are, compared to how connected they would be in a random network.
The Louvain algorithm is a hierarchical clustering algorithm, that recursively merges communities into a single node and executes the modularity clustering on the condensed graphs.
Source: https://neo4j.com/docs/graph-data-science/current/algorithms/louvain/https://towardsdatascience.com/louvain-algorithm-93fde589f58c












Clustering Results
Participants within the same cluster can be regarded as people with similar sleeping conditions.






Clustering Treemap



Significant Variables in Clustering

[1] "waking_too_early_f20535_0_0"                                        
[2] "sleeping_too_much_f20534_0_0"                                       
[3] "sleeplessness_insomnia_f1200_0_0"                                   
[4] "degree_bothered_by_trouble_sleeping_in_the_last_3_months_f21061_0_0"
[5] "trouble_falling_or_staying_asleep_or_sleeping_too_much_f20517_0_0"  
[6] "trouble_falling_asleep_f20533_0_0"                                  
[7] "sleep_duration_f1160_0_0"                                           
















Heatmap
All the significant variables in sleep clustering are correlated. As the objective of clustering is to group data points based on similar sleeping patterns, the correlation between sleeping variables may actually be meaningful for the analysis. We can further interpret the results to generate a sleep profile for each participant.

articles.title: Prediction
articles.description: Incorporating accelerometry data to predict sleeping conditions
articles.contents:
Predict sleep outcome using only demographic variables


Call:
 randomForest(formula = as.formula(paste(target, "~", paste(predictors,      collapse = " + "))), data = train_data, ntree = 500, mtry = sqrt(length(predictors)))

Predict sleep outcome using demographic variables + accelerometry


Call:
 randomForest(formula = as.formula(paste(target, "~", paste(a_predictors,      collapse = " + "))), data = a_train_data, ntree = 500, mtry = sqrt(length(predictors))) 
               Type of random forest: classification
                     Number of trees: 500
No. of variables tried at each split: 2

        OOB estimate of  error rate: 79.74%

Predictor significance

      weight_f21002_0_0            low_activity 
             2118.41411              2058.26818 
           mid_activity           high_activity 
             2051.46715              1946.05916 
standing_height_f50_0_0   year_of_birth_f34_0_0 
             1691.86763              1498.19034 
            sex_f31_0_0 
               92.05787 

Incorporating activity scores calculated from accelerometry data can increase accuracy rate of our random forest model by 18.75%. Activity score variables turn out to show significance compared to other demographic variables. Based on our findings, we can infer that accelerometry data has the potential to serve as an additional tool for predicting sleep conditions.
However, the accuracy rate is still low. This is because the independent variables (especially the activity scores) represent summary data, which may have resulted in the loss of significant information during the aggregation process.” This can be solved in the future by taking full advantage of raw accelerometry data (beyond our current scope).
